Objectives This review aims to uncover the provision of PHC services by CPs in LMICs and identify barriers to these services, as well as strategies to overcome them. Methods Medline, CINAHL, Google Scholar, and others were searched for articles published between 2000 and 2022 that reported on CPs’ provision of PHC services in LMICs. Eligible studies were evaluated, and data were extracted and assessed for quality using the mixed methods appraisal tool (MMAT). Results Only 13 studies had a high quality rating, less than a quarter ( n n n n n n n n Conclusion Pharmacists in LMICs play a vital role in PHC despite the presence of some barriers. Policies that recognise pharmacists as PHC providers and continuous training could improve their services. These clinicians are responsible for addressing most personal health care needs, building lasting partnerships with patients, and working within the context of families and communities [ 39 64 112 113 49 168 169 The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the vulnerabilities present in healthcare systems of low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). This has created an urgent need to focus on initiatives that will adequately address the needs of these populations [ 63 149 Community pharmacists play a crucial role in delivering pharmaceutical care services, which are essential for achieving universal health coverage (UHC). Although the involvement of community pharmacists in primary health care (PHC) in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) has increased in recent years, there remains a lack of recent published systematic reviews addressing these roles [ 6 97 149 174 Methods A systematic review of the literature was conducted to identify articles assessing the roles of CPs in primary health care within low- and middle-income countries. The protocol was registered on PROSPERO (registration ID: CRD42023357312) and subsequently published in a relevant journal [ 64 100 Search strategy The search strategy was developed in collaboration with two members of the research team (EWH and RNO) and an academic librarian. It focused on studies published in English from January 2000 to December 2022. This timeframe was chosen to encompass research conducted since the United Nations member states declared the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) in 2000. We believe that these MDGs had a significant impact on the health systems in these regions. Studies were included if: (i) focused on PHC services by community pharmacists, (ii) published between 2000 and 2022 in language English, (iii) original research, (iv) conducted in community pharmacies in LMICs, and (v) full-text information is available. Exclusion criteria Studies were excluded if (i) Not original research, (ii) not conducted in community pharmacy setting, (iii) published before year 2000, (iv) carried out in high income countries, (v) published in languages other than English. The relevant data from the included studies were independently assessed by the two authors. From these studies, information were extracted based on the specific PHC roles of CPs in the country setting, barriers, and recommendations. [ 82 26 The most common barrier preventing CPs from providing PHC services in this review is a lack of government policies or an updated laws and regulations, such as having old pharmacy laws that do not match the current reality and a lack of standard guidance on providing primary care. The respective governments has engaged health care practitioners in preventing non-communicable diseases, but the specific roles of CPs have not been clearly outlined [ 50 60 154 135 154 101 135 44 86 162 Another barrier is a lack of collaboration with other healthcare professionals, especially physicians. This barrier was delineated in other studies [ 44 86 129 164 171 76 44 44 69 84 11 41 44 58 80 42 50 98 Enhancing the roles of community pharmacists (CPs) in primary care requires continuous pharmacy education (CPE) and supportive government policies. These elements not only empower pharmacists but also improve healthcare delivery in various settings, particularly in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). A related study highlighted the need for mandatory professional development in complementary and alternative medicines [ 161 17 To enhance the impact of community pharmacists, policy reforms are needed to officially recognize pharmacists as primary healthcare providers and expand their clinical responsibilities [ 113 18 The major strength of this systematic review is the mixed methods approach without limitations due to the study design. However, this review has several limitations. First, there may be bias in reporting the primary health care practices of community pharmacists in LMICs, which is evident in the relatively few studies included in the review. Second, we limited our systematic review to only scientific articles. There is potential for researchers to be unwilling to publish unfavourable outcomes, and the number of studies indexed in databases in LMICs may be unequal. Third, the presence of few published articles in these regions may not reflect the state of primary care pharmacy practice. This systematic review is also limited due to the use of indexing databases and our search strategy. Conclusion The evidence suggests that community pharmacists in LMICs provide crucial PHC services, the most common being health education, referral of patients to GPs, medication review, point of care testing, self-care for chronic illnesses and promoting access to essential medicines, infection prevention and control measures, health education and triage of suspected COVID-19 patients. The most prominent barriers to these services include a lack of government policies and updated laws, lack of time and reimbursement effective collaboration in patient care, physical barriers and limited knowledge in patient care. To mitigate these barriers, there is a need for a policy framework that would designate community pharmacists as PHC providers and continuous professional development as a way of improving PHC services.
